data.source: OECD STAN database (relative manufacturing employment); additional macroeconomic and trade variables from OECD-related sources (specific datasets not stated)
data.sample_size: Up to 612 observations compiled; 566 observations used after exclusions/missing data
data.notes: Panel data with some missing observations; seven outliers excluded using Hadi robust outlier detection (e.g., Norway 1999–2003, Belgium 1998–1999); two-way fixed effects with period dummies; explanatory variables lagged one year; identified serial and spatial correlation and group-wise heteroscedasticity; GLS used (no R-squared reported with GLS).

method.description: The study analyzes deindustrialization across 18 OECD countries (1970–2003) using two-way fixed-effects panel regressions. The dependent variable is relative manufacturing employment. Key predictors include national affluence (GDP per capita with higher-order terms), unbalanced productivity growth (manufacturing minus services, cumulative since 1970), and globalization metrics (North–South trade flows, North–North trade, FDI). Models address serial/spatial correlation and heteroscedasticity via GLS; all covariates are lagged one year. Outliers are removed using a robust algorithm, and separate equations assess indirect effects on affluence and productivity.
steps: Assemble panel for 18 OECD countries from 1970–2003 (country-year observations).
Construct dependent variable: relative manufacturing employment (percentage of workforce) from OECD STAN.
Collect GDP per capita and create linear, squared, and cubed terms to capture non-linear effects (national affluence).
Compute unbalanced productivity growth as cumulative real value added per worker in manufacturing minus services since 1970 (include squared term if indicated by diagnostics).

Compile globalization measures: North–South imports and exports, North–North trade (scaled to GDP); FDI net outflows; and unemployment rate as a control (sources implied to be OECD; specific series not stated).
Create five-year period dummies for time fixed effects and include country fixed effects (two-way FE).
Lag all explanatory variables by one year to reflect delayed effects.
Diagnose serial correlation, spatial correlation, and group-wise heteroscedasticity; adopt GLS estimator compatible with two-way FE to correct these issues.
Identify and drop outliers using the Hadi robust outlier detection algorithm (seven cases, including Norway 1999–2003 and Belgium 1998–1999).
Estimate three core models: domestic drivers, global drivers, and combined; and estimate additional equations for indirect effects on affluence and productivity.
Conduct Hausman test to justify FE over RE; use Breusch–Pagan test to assess independence of disturbances across equations.
Summarize contributions of affluence, trade, and productivity to overall deindustrialization; interpret coefficients and signs across models.
method.models: Two-way fixed-effects panel regression estimated via GLS with corrections for serial and spatial correlation and group-wise heteroscedasticity; period (time) and country fixed effects; models estimated separately for RME, national affluence, and unbalanced productivity growth; FE preferred to RE based on Hausman tests. Appendix notes FE-3SLS results.
method.outcome_variable: Relative manufacturing employment (percentage of total workforce)
method.independent_variables: National affluence (GDP per capita, linear/squared/cubed terms); unbalanced productivity growth (manufacturing minus services, cumulative since 1970); North–South imports; North–South exports; North–North trade; foreign direct investment (net outflows); unemployment rate; time (period) dummies; all explanatory variables lagged one year.
method.control_variables: Unemployment rate; five-year period (time) dummies; initial German reunification control considered but dropped as insignificant.
method.tools_software: Stata; Hadi robust outlier detection algorithm

results.summary: Affluence is the strongest driver of deindustrialization: as incomes rise, manufacturing employment first increases and then declines, with the net effect at higher affluence being negative. Faster productivity growth in manufacturing relative to services reduces manufacturing employment. Globalization contributes via trade: imports from the South displace more manufacturing jobs than exports to the South create; imports from the North also negatively affect employment. FDI shows no significant relationship. Estimated contributions attribute roughly one-third of deindustrialization to rising affluence, with additional shares from North–South trade and unbalanced productivity growth. Domestic factors account for over half of the deindustrialization observed.
